metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Cookies
Cookies let you store user information in web pages.
content.html: Cookies let you store user information in web pages.

content.text: What are Cookies?
Cookies are data, stored in small text files, on your computer.
content.html: Cookies are data, stored in small text files, on your computer.

content.text: When a web server has sent a web page to a browser, the connection is shut down, and the server forgets everything about the user.
content.html: When a web server has sent a web page to a browser, the connection is shut down, and the server forgets everything about the user.

content.text: Cookies were invented to solve the problem "how to remember information about the user":
content.html: Cookies were invented to solve the problem "how to remember information about the user":

content.text: Cookies are saved in name-value pairs like:
content.html: Cookies are saved in name-value pairs like:

content.code_html: username = John Doe

content.text: When a browser requests a web page from a server, cookies belonging to the page are added to the request. This way the server gets the necessary data to "remember" information about users.
content.html: When a browser requests a web page from a server, cookies belonging to the page are added to the request. This way the server gets the necessary data to "remember" information about users.

content.text: None of the examples below will work if your browser has local cookies support turned off.
content.html: None of the examples below will work if your browser has local cookies support turned off.

content.text: Create a Cookie with JavaScript
JavaScript can create, read, and delete cookies with the document.cookie property.
content.html: JavaScript can create, read, and delete cookies with the document.cookie property.

content.text: With JavaScript, a cookie can be created like this:
content.html: With JavaScript, a cookie can be created like this:

content.code_html: document.cookie = "username=John Doe";

content.text: You can also add an expiry date (in UTC time). By default, the cookie is deleted when the browser is closed:
content.html: You can also add an expiry date (in UTC time). By default, the cookie is deleted when the browser is closed:

content.code_html: document.cookie = "username=John Doe; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC";

content.text: With a path parameter, you can tell the browser what path the cookie belongs to. By default, the cookie belongs to the current page.
content.html: With a path parameter, you can tell the browser what path the cookie belongs to. By default, the cookie belongs to the current page.

syntaxHighlighting.text: document.cookie = "username=John Doe; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC; path=/";

content.code: document.cookie = "username=John Doe; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC; path=/";

syntax_highlighting.text: document.cookie = "username=John Doe; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC; path=/";

content.code_html: document.cookie = "username=John Doe; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC; path=/";

syntax_highlighting_data.text: document.cookie = "username=John Doe; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC; path=/";

content.text: Read a Cookie with JavaScript
With JavaScript, cookies can be read like this:
content.html: With JavaScript, cookies can be read like this:

content.code_html: let x = document.cookie;

content.text: document.cookie will return all cookies in one string much like: cookie1=value; cookie2=value; cookie3=value;
content.html: document.cookie will return all cookies in one string much like: cookie1=value; cookie2=value; cookie3=value;

content.text: Change a Cookie with JavaScript
With JavaScript, you can change a cookie the same way as you create it:
content.html: With JavaScript, you can change a cookie the same way as you create it:

syntaxHighlighting.text: document.cookie = "username=John Smith; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC; path=/";

content.code: document.cookie = "username=John Smith; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC; path=/";

syntax_highlighting.text: document.cookie = "username=John Smith; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC; path=/";

content.code_html: document.cookie = "username=John Smith; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC; path=/";

syntax_highlighting_data.text: document.cookie = "username=John Smith; expires=Thu, 18 Dec 2013 12:00:00 UTC; path=/";

content.text: The old cookie is overwritten.
content.html: The old cookie is overwritten.

content.text: Delete a Cookie with JavaScript
Deleting a cookie is very simple.
content.html: Deleting a cookie is very simple.

content.text: You don't have to specify a cookie value when you delete a cookie.
content.html: You don't have to specify a cookie value when you delete a cookie.

content.text: Just set the expires parameter to a past date:
content.html: Just set the expires parameter to a past date:

content.code_html: document.cookie = "username=; expires=Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 UTC; path=/;";

content.text: You should define the cookie path to ensure that you delete the right cookie.
content.html: You should define the cookie path to ensure that you delete the right cookie.

content.text: Some browsers will not let you delete a cookie if you don't specify the path.
content.html: Some browsers will not let you delete a cookie if you don't specify the path.

content.text: The Cookie String
The document.cookie property looks like a normal text string. But it is not.
content.html: The document.cookie property looks like a normal text string. But it is not.

content.text: Even if you write a whole cookie string to document.cookie, when you read it out again, you can only see the name-value pair of it.
content.html: Even if you write a whole cookie string to document.cookie, when you read it out again, you can only see the name-value pair of it.

content.text: If you set a new cookie, older cookies are not overwritten. The new cookie is added to document.cookie, so if you read document.cookie again you will get something like:
content.html: If you set a new cookie, older cookies are not overwritten. The new cookie is added to document.cookie, so if you read document.cookie again you will get something like:

content.text: cookie1 = value; cookie2 = value;
content.html: cookie1 = value; cookie2 = value;

content.text: Display All Cookies Create Cookie 1 Create Cookie 2 Delete Cookie 1 Delete Cookie 2
If you want to find the value of one specified cookie, you must write a JavaScript function that searches for the cookie value in the cookie string.
content.html: If you want to find the value of one specified cookie, you must write a JavaScript function that searches for the cookie value in the cookie string.

content.text: JavaScript Cookie Example
In the example to follow, we will create a cookie that stores the name of a visitor.
content.html: In the example to follow, we will create a cookie that stores the name of a visitor.

content.text: The first time a visitor arrives to the web page, he/she will be asked to fill in his/her name. The name is then stored in a cookie.
content.html: The first time a visitor arrives to the web page, he/she will be asked to fill in his/her name. The name is then stored in a cookie.

content.text: The next time the visitor arrives at the same page, he/she will get a welcome message.
content.html: The next time the visitor arrives at the same page, he/she will get a welcome message.

content.text: For the example we will create 3 JavaScript functions:
content.html: For the example we will create 3 JavaScript functions:

content.text: A Function to Set a Cookie
First, we create a function that stores the name of the visitor in a cookie variable:
content.html: First, we create a function that stores the name of the visitor in a cookie variable:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
function setCookie(cname, cvalue, exdays) {
   const d = new Date();  d.setTime(d.getTime() + (exdays*24*60*60*1000));  let expires = "expires="+ d.toUTCString();  document.cookie = cname + "=" + cvalue + ";" + expires + ";path=/";}

content.code:
function setCookie(cname, cvalue, exdays) {
const d = new Date();  d.setTime(d.getTime() + (exdays*24*60*60*1000));  let expires = "expires="+ d.toUTCString();  document.cookie = cname + "=" + cvalue + ";" + expires + ";path=/";}

syntax_highlighting.text:
function setCookie(cname, cvalue, exdays) {
   const d = new Date();  d.setTime(d.getTime() + (exdays*24*60*60*1000));  let expires = "expires="+ d.toUTCString();  document.cookie = cname + "=" + cvalue + ";" + expires + ";path=/";}

content.code_html:
function setCookie(cname, cvalue, exdays) {
  const d = new Date();
  d.setTime(d.getTime() + (exdays*24*60*60*1000));
  let expires = "expires="+ d.toUTCString();
  document.cookie = cname + "=" + cvalue + ";" + expires + ";path=/";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
function setCookie(cname, cvalue, exdays) {
   const d = new Date();  d.setTime(d.getTime() + (exdays*24*60*60*1000));  let expires = "expires="+ d.toUTCString();  document.cookie = cname + "=" + cvalue + ";" + expires + ";path=/";}

content.text: Example explained:
content.html: Example explained:

content.text: The parameters of the function above are the name of the cookie (cname), the value of the cookie (cvalue), and the number of days until the cookie should expire (exdays).
content.html: The parameters of the function above are the name of the cookie (cname), the value of the cookie (cvalue), and the number of days until the cookie should expire (exdays).

content.text: The function sets a cookie by adding together the cookiename, the cookie value, and the expires string.
content.html: The function sets a cookie by adding together the cookiename, the cookie value, and the expires string.

content.text: A Function to Get a Cookie
Then, we create a function that returns the value of a specified cookie:
content.html: Then, we create a function that returns the value of a specified cookie:

content.code_html:
function getCookie(cname) {
  let name = cname + "=";
  let decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
  let ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  for(let i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    let c = ca[i];
    while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
      c = c.substring(1);
    }
    if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
      return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    }
  }
  return "";
}

content.text: Function explained:
content.html: Function explained:

content.text: Take the cookiename as parameter (cname).
content.html: Take the cookiename as parameter (cname).

content.text: Create a variable (name) with the text to search for (cname + "=").
content.html: Create a variable (name) with the text to search for (cname + "=").

content.text: Decode the cookie string, to handle cookies with special characters, e.g. '$'
content.html: Decode the cookie string, to handle cookies with special characters, e.g. '$'

content.text: Split document.cookie on semicolons into an array called ca (ca = decodedCookie.split(';')).
content.html: Split document.cookie on semicolons into an array called ca (ca = decodedCookie.split(';')).

content.text: Loop through the ca array (i = 0; i < ca.length; i++), and read out each value c = ca[i]).
content.html: Loop through the ca array (i = 0; i < ca.length; i++), and read out each value c = ca[i]).

content.text: If the cookie is found (c.indexOf(name) == 0), return the value of the cookie (c.substring(name.length, c.length).
content.html: If the cookie is found (c.indexOf(name) == 0), return the value of the cookie (c.substring(name.length, c.length).

content.text: If the cookie is not found, return "".
content.html: If the cookie is not found, return "".

content.text: A Function to Check a Cookie
Last, we create the function that checks if a cookie is set.
content.html: Last, we create the function that checks if a cookie is set.

content.text: If the cookie is set it will display a greeting.
content.html: If the cookie is set it will display a greeting.

content.text: If the cookie is not set, it will display a prompt box, asking for the name of the user, and stores the username cookie for 365 days, by calling the setCookie function:
content.html: If the cookie is not set, it will display a prompt box, asking for the name of the user, and stores the username cookie for 365 days, by calling the setCookie function:

content.code_html:
function checkCookie() {
  let username = getCookie("username");
  if (username != "") {
   alert("Welcome again " + username);
  } else {
    username = prompt("Please enter your name:", "");
    if (username != "" && username != null) {
      setCookie("username", username, 365);
    }
  }
}

content.text: All Together Now

content.code_html:
function setCookie(cname, cvalue, exdays) {
  const d = new Date();
  d.setTime(d.getTime() + (exdays * 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000));
  let expires = "expires="+d.toUTCString();
  document.cookie = cname + "=" + cvalue + ";" + expires + ";path=/";
}

function getCookie(cname) {
  let name = cname + "=";
  let ca = document.cookie.split(';');
  for(let i = 0; i < ca.length; i++) {
    let c = ca[i];
    while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
      c = c.substring(1);
    }
    if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
      return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    }
  }
  return "";
}

function checkCookie() {
  let user = getCookie("username");
  if (user != "") {
    alert("Welcome again " + user);
  } else {
    user = prompt("Please enter your name:", "");
    if (user != "" && user != null) {
      setCookie("username", user, 365);
    }
  }
}

content.text: The example above runs the checkCookie() function when the page loads.
content.html: The example above runs the checkCookie() function when the page loads.
